1.1: This is the special dream of Isaiah the son of Amoz, about Judah and Jerusalem, which he saw during the rule of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
1.2: Listen, O heavens, and hear, O earth, for the Lord has spoken: “I have brought up and have taken care of sons, but they have turned against Me.
1.3: An ox knows its owner. A donkey knows where to find the food its owner gives it. But Israel does not know. My people do not understand.”
1.4: O sinful nation, people weighed down with sin, children of those who do wrong, sons who act in a sinful way! They have left the Lord. They have hated the Holy One of Israel. They have turned away from Him.
1.5: Where will you be punished again, since you still fight against the Lord? Your whole head is sick, and your whole heart is weak.
1.6: From the bottom of the foot even to the head, there is no good part. There are only sores from beatings and open sores. They are not taken care of or covered or made soft with oil.
1.7: Your land lies waste. Your cities are burned with fire. Strangers are eating the food of your fields in front of you. It lies waste, as destroyed by strangers.
1.8: The people of Zion are left like a tent in a grape-field, like a watchman’s house in a vegetable field, like a city closed in by armies.
1.9: If the Lord of All had not left some people, we would have all been destroyed like those who lived in the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah.
1.10: Hear the Word of the Lord, you rulers of Sodom. Listen to the teaching of our God, you people of Gomorrah.
1.11: “What are your many gifts given in worship to Me?” says the Lord. “I have had enough burnt gifts of rams and the fat of cattle. And I am not pleased with the blood of bulls, lambs, or goats.
1.12: When you come to show yourselves before Me, who says you must walk and walk around My open spaces?
1.13: Do not bring your gifts of no worth any more. Your special perfume is a hated thing to Me. The new moon and Day of Rest, this calling together of the people, I cannot put up with. I cannot put up with your sin and your meetings of worship.
1.14: I hate your new moons and your special suppers. They have become heavy upon Me. I am tired of carrying them.
1.15: So when you spread out your hands in prayer, I will hide My eyes from you. Even if you pray many times, I will not listen. Your hands are full of blood.
1.16: “Wash yourselves. Make yourselves clean. Take your sinful actions from My eyes. Stop doing sinful things.
1.17: Learn to do good. Look for what is right and fair. Speak strong words to those who make it hard for people. Stand up for the rights of those who have no parents. Help the woman whose husband has died.
1.18: “Come now, let us think about this together,” says the Lord. “Even though your sins are bright red, they will be as white as snow. Even though they are dark red, they will be like wool.
1.19: If you are willing and obey, you will eat the best of the land.
1.20: But if you are not willing and turn against Me, you will be destroyed by the sword.” For the mouth of the Lord has spoken.
1.21: The faithful city has become like a woman who sells the use of her body. At one time she was full of what was right and fair! Those who are right and good lived in her, but now those who kill.
1.22: Your silver has lost its worth. Your wine is mixed with water.
1.23: Your rulers have turned against what is right. They are the friends of robbers. Every one loves to get pay in secret for wrong-doing, and they run after gifts. They do not stand for the rights of those who have no parents. And they never hear the cry for help of the woman whose husband has died.
1.24: So the Lord God of All, the Powerful One of Israel, says, “I will put an end to those who fight against Me. I will punish those who hate Me.
1.25: I will turn My hand against you and burn what is of no worth in you. And I will take away from you all that is not pure.
1.26: Then I will give you judges as at the first, and your wise men as at the beginning. After that you will be called the city that is right and good, a faithful city.”
1.27: Zion will be saved by being fair. Those who are sorry for their sins and turn from them will be saved by being right and good.
1.28: But wrong-doers and sinners will be crushed together. Those who turn away from the Lord will come to an end.
1.29: For you will be ashamed of the oaks where you worshiped. You will be ashamed of the gardens you have chosen.
1.30: For you will be like an oak tree whose leaf dries up, or like a garden that has no water.
1.31: The strong man will become easy to burn, and his work also a fire. They will burn together, and there will be no one to put the fire out.

2.1: This is what Isaiah the son of Amoz saw about Judah and Jerusalem that was coming:
2.2: In the last days, the mountain of the house of the Lord will be the most important of the mountains. It will be raised above the hills. All the nations will come to it.
2.3: Many people will come and say, “Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord, to the house of the God of Jacob. Then He will teach us about His ways, that we may walk in His paths. For the Law will go out from Zion, and the Word of the Lord from Jerusalem.”
2.4: He will judge between the nations, and will decide for many people. And they will beat their swords into plows, and their spears into knives for cutting vines. Nation will not lift up sword against nation, and they will not learn about war anymore.
2.5: Come, people of Jacob. Let us walk in the light of the Lord.
2.6: For You have left Your people, the family of Jacob, because they are filled with the sinful ways of the East. They use secret ways to tell the future like the Philistines. And they make agreements with the children of strangers.
2.7: Their land is filled with silver and gold. There is no end to their riches. Their land is filled with horses also. And there is no end to their war-wagons.
2.8: Their land is filled with false gods. They worship the work of their hands, that which their fingers have made.
2.9: So pride has been taken away from the poor man, and important men have been put to shame. Do not forgive them.
2.10: Go into the rock and hide in the dust from the anger of the Lord and from the shining-greatness of His power.
2.11: The proud look of man will be put to shame. The pride of men will be taken away. And the Lord alone will be honored in that day.
2.12: On that day the Lord of All will be against everyone who is proud and feels important, and against all who are honored. They will be put to shame.
2.13: He will be against all the cedar trees of Lebanon that are tall and honored, and against all the oak trees of Bashan.
2.14: He will be against all the high mountains, against all the high hills,
2.15: against every high tower, and against every strong wall.
2.16: He will be against all the ships of Tarshish, and against all the beautiful boats.
2.17: The pride of man will be taken away. What men honor will be put to shame. The Lord alone will be honored in that day.
2.18: All the false gods will be gone.
2.19: Men will go into the caves of the rocks and into holes of the earth because of the anger of the Lord and the shining-greatness of His power when He rises up to shake the earth.
2.20: In that day men will take their false gods of silver and gold which they made for themselves to worship and will throw them away to the moles and the bats.
2.21: They will go into the caves of the rocks and mountains. They will try to hide from the anger of the Lord and from the shining-greatness of His power, when He rises up to shake the earth.
2.22: Stop trusting in man. He has only a breath in his nose. Why should he be honored?

3.1: See, the Lord, the Lord God of All, is going to take away from Jerusalem and Judah all they have to keep themselves alive and safe, all the bread and all the water.
3.2: He will take away the strong man, the man of war, the man who judges, the man who tells what will happen in the future, the man who uses secret ways, and the leader.
3.3: He will take away the captain of fifty, the man of honor, the wise man, the able workman, and the one who uses secret powers.
3.4: I will make boys their rulers. Foolish children will rule over them.
3.5: The people will make it hard for each other. Each one will hurt the other, and each one will be hurt by his neighbor. The younger will show anger toward the older. And the man who is not respected will show anger toward the man of honor.
3.6: A man will take hold of his brother in his father’s house, saying, “You have a coat. You will be our ruler. This destroyed city will be under your rule.”
3.7: In that day he will call out, “I can not be of help to you. For in my house there is no bread or coat. You should not choose me to be ruler of the people.”
3.8: For Jerusalem has no strength, and Judah has fallen, because their speaking and their actions are against the Lord. They have turned against His shining-greatness.
3.9: The look on their faces speaks against them. They show their sin like Sodom. They do not even hide it. It is bad for them! For they have brought trouble upon themselves.
3.10: Tell those who are right and good that it will go well for them. For they will enjoy the fruit of what they do.
3.11: It will be bad for the sinful man! It will not go well for him, for what he has done will be done to him.
3.12: O My people! Children make it hard for them. And women rule over them. O My people! Your leaders lead you in the wrong way. You do not know which path to take.
3.13: The Lord is ready to say what He thinks and stands to judge the people.
3.14: The Lord judges the leaders and rulers of His people: “It is you who have destroyed the grape-field. What had belonged to the poor is in your houses.
3.15: What do you mean by crushing My people, and grinding the faces of the poor?” says the Lord God of All.
3.16: The Lord said, “The daughters of Zion are proud. They walk with heads held high and a wrong desire in their eyes. They walk with short steps, making noise with the chains on their ankles.
3.17: So the Lord will make sores come upon the heads of the daughters of Zion, and take the hair from their head.
3.18: In that day the Lord will take away the beauty of their ankle chains, headbands, moon-like objects,
3.19: rings worn on their ears and arms, face-coverings,
3.20: head-dresses, leg-chains, wide belts, perfume boxes, objects with secret powers,
3.23: hand mirrors, underclothes, head-coverings, and face-coverings.
3.24: Instead of sweet perfume there will be a bad smell. Instead of a belt there will be a rope. Instead of well set hair there will be no hair. Instead of fine clothes they will wear cloth made from hair. And there will be burnt marks instead of beauty.
3.25: Your men will fall by the sword. Your strong ones will fall in battle.
3.26: Jerusalem’s gates will be filled with sorrow. She will sit on the ground, laid waste and empty.

4.1: Seven women will take hold of one man in that day, saying, “We will eat our own bread and wear our own clothes. Only let us be called by your name. Take away our shame!”
4.2: In that day the Branch of the Lord will be beautiful and shining with greatness. The fruit of the earth will be the pride and the beauty of those of Israel who are still alive.
4.3: He who is left in Zion and stays in Jerusalem will be called holy, everyone who has been written down among the living in Jerusalem.
4.4: The Lord will wash away the sin of the daughters of Zion. He will wash away the blood that was shed in Jerusalem, by the spirit of punishment and the spirit of fire.
4.5: Then the Lord will cover the whole land of Mount Zion and her people with a cloud of smoke during the day, and a bright fire that shines during the night. The Lord’s shining-greatness will cover everything.
4.6: It will be a covering from the heat during the day and it will keep the people safe from the storm and the rain.

5.1: Let me sing for my loved one a love song about His grape-field: My loved one had a grape-field on a hill that grows much fruit.
5.2: He dug all around it and took away its stones, and planted it with the best vine. He built a tower in the center of it, and cut out a place in it for crushing grapes. Then He expected it to give good grapes, but it gave only wild grapes.
5.3: “And now, O people living in Jerusalem and men of Judah, judge between Me and My grape-field.
5.4: What more was there to do for My grape-field that I have not done for it? When I expected it to give good grapes, why did it give wild grapes?
5.5: Now I will tell you what I am going to do to My grape-field. I will take away its fence and it will be destroyed. I will break down its wall and it will be crushed under foot.
5.6: I will make it a waste. It will not be taken care of, and thistles and thorns will come up. I will also tell the clouds not to rain on it.”
5.7: For the grape-field of the Lord of All is the people of Israel, and the men of Judah are the vines He planted. So He looked for what is right and fair, but He saw blood poured out. He looked for what is right and good, but He heard a cry of those in trouble.
5.8: It is bad for those who join house to house and field to field until there is no empty space, and you have to live alone in the land.
5.9: The Lord of All has sworn in my ears, “For sure, many houses will be laid waste. Large and beautiful houses will be empty.
5.10: For ten fields of vines will give only eleven large bottles of wine. And 110 jars of seed will give only eleven jars of grain.”
5.11: It is bad for those who get up early in the morning to run after strong drink! It is bad for those who stay up late in the evening that they may get drunk!
5.12: They have harps, a noise-maker, a horn, and wine at their special suppers. But they do not think about the works of the Lord. They do not think of the work of His hands.
5.13: So My people are taken away to strange lands because they have not been wise. Their men of honor are dying because they are hungry. Their people are dried up because they are thirsty.
5.14: So the grave has become larger and has opened its mouth wide. And Jerusalem’s greatness, her people, her sounds of wild joy, and those who are happy with sin go down into it.
5.15: Man’s pride will be taken away. Important men will be put to shame. The eyes of the proud also will be put to shame.
5.16: But the Lord of All will be honored in what is right and fair. The holy God will show Himself holy in what is right and good.
5.17: Then the lambs will eat as in their field. And strangers will eat in the waste places of the rich.
5.18: It is bad for those who pull sin along with ropes of lies, who pull wrong-doing as with a wagon rope,
5.19: who say, “Let Him hurry. Let Him be quick to do His work, that we may see it. Let the plan of the Holy One of Israel be done, that we may know it!”
5.20: It is bad for those who call what is sinful good, and good sinful, who say dark is light and light is dark, who make bitter sweet, and sweet bitter!
5.21: It is bad for those who are wise in their own eyes, and who think they know a lot!
5.22: It is bad for those who are good at drinking wine, and are proud as they mix strong drink!
5.23: They take money in secret for saying that bad people are good. And they take away the rights of those who are not guilty.
5.24: So, as fire destroys what is left of the cut grain and dry grass falls into the fire, so their root will waste away and their flower blow away like dust. For they have turned away from the Law of the Lord of All. They have hated the Word of the Holy One of Israel.
5.25: Because of this the anger of the Lord has burned against His people. He has put out His hand against them and destroyed them. The mountains shook. Their dead bodies lay like waste in the center of the streets. For all this His anger is not turned away but His hand is still put out.
5.26: He will raise up flags as a sign to the nations far away. He will call for them from the ends of the earth, and they will hurry to come.
5.27: Not one of them is tired or falls. No one sleeps. Not a belt is loosened at the waist, or a shoe string broken.
5.28: Their arrows are sharp, and their bows are ready. The feet of their horses are like hard stone. And the wheels of their war-wagons are like a strong-wind.
5.29: Their noise is like that of a female lion. They sound like young lions. They make an angry noise as they take their food, and carry it away where no one can take it from them.
5.30: In that day they will make an angry noise over it like the noise of the sea. If one looks to the land, he will see darkness and trouble. Even the light is made dark by its clouds.

6.1: In the year of King Uzziah’s death, I saw the Lord sitting on a throne, high and honored. His long clothing spread out and filled the house of God.
6.2: Seraphim stood above Him, each having six wings. With two he covered his face, and with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew.
6.3: One called out to another and said, “Holy, holy, holy, is the Lord of All. The whole earth is full of His shining-greatness.”
6.4: And the base of the doorways shook at the voice of him who called out, while the house of God was filled with smoke.
6.5: Then I said, “It is bad for me, for I am destroyed! Because I am a man whose lips are unclean. And I live among a people whose lips are unclean. For my eyes have seen the King, the Lord of All.”
6.6: Then one of the seraphim flew to me, with a burning coal which he had taken from the altar using a special tool.
6.7: He touched my mouth with it, and said, “See, this has touched your lips, and your guilt is taken away. Your sin is forgiven.”
6.8: Then I heard the voice of the Lord, saying, “Whom should I send? Who will go for Us?” Then I said, “Here am I. Send me!”
6.9: He said, “Go, and tell these people, ‘You hear and hear but do not understand. You look and look but do not see.’
6.10: Make the hearts of these people hard. May their ears hear little and their eyes see little. Or they will see with their eyes and hear with their ears and understand with their hearts, and turn again and be healed.”
6.11: Then I said, “Lord, how long?” And He answered, “Until cities are destroyed and empty, and until houses are without people and the land is laid waste.
6.12: Until the Lord has taken men far away, and there are many places with no people in the land.
6.13: Yet one tenth part of the people will stay in it. But it will be burned again, like an oak tree whose roots are still there when it is cut down. The holy seed is all that will be left (of Israel).”

7.1: In the days of Ahaz the son of Jotham, son of Uzziah, king of Judah, King Rezin of Syria and Pekah the son of Remaliah, king of Israel, went up to make war against Jerusalem. But they could not win the battle.
7.2: When the family of David was told, “Syria has joined with Ephraim,” his heart and the hearts of his people shook as trees shake with the wind.
7.3: Then the Lord said to Isaiah, “Now you and your son Shear-jashub go out to meet Ahaz at the end of the ditch of the upper pool on the road to the Fuller’s Field.
7.4: Say to him, ‘Be careful and quiet. Do not be afraid or weak in your heart because of these two pieces of burnt and smoking wood. Do not be afraid of the burning anger of Rezin and Syria and the son of Remaliah.
7.5: Syria, with Ephraim and the son of Remaliah, have made sinful plans against you, saying,
7.6: “Let us go up against Judah and make the people very afraid. Let us break open its walls, and make the son of Tabeel its king.”
7.7: But the Lord God says, “This plan will not work. It will not happen.
7.8: For the head of Syria is Damascus and the head of Damascus is Rezin. (Within another sixty-five years Ephraim will be destroyed so that it is no longer a people.)
7.9: The head of Ephraim is Samaria. And the head of Samaria is the son of Remaliah. If you will not believe, for sure you will not last.”’”
7.10: Then the Lord spoke again to Ahaz, saying,
7.11: “Ask for something special to see from the Lord your God. Ask for it to be as deep as the place of the dead or as high as heaven.”
7.12: But Ahaz said, “I will not ask. I will not test the Lord.”
7.13: Then Isaiah said, “Listen now, O people of David! Is it too small a thing for you to test men, that you will test my God as well?
7.14: So the Lord Himself will give you a special thing to see: A young woman, who has never had a man, will give birth to a son. She will give Him the name Immanuel.
7.15: He will eat milk and honey when He knows enough to have nothing to do with wrong-doing and chooses good.
7.16: For before the boy knows to turn away from what is bad and choose good, the land whose two kings you are afraid of will be left empty.”
7.17: The Lord will bring upon you and your people and your father’s house such days as have never come since the day that Ephraim was divided from Judah. He is going to bring the king of Assyria on you.
7.18: In that day the Lord will call for flies that are in the farthest part of the rivers of Egypt, and for bees that are in the land of Assyria.
7.19: They will all come and stay in the narrow valleys, on the hill-sides, on the thorn bushes, and in the fields.
7.20: In that day the Lord will use the king of Assyria from the other side of the Euphrates to cut off the hair from your head, your legs, and your face.
7.21: In that day a man will keep alive a young cow and two sheep.
7.22: And because they give much milk, he will have all he can use. For everyone who is left in the land will have milk and honey to eat.
7.23: In that day, every place where there used to be a thousand vines, worth a thousand pieces of silver, will be thistles and thorns.
7.24: Men will go there with bows and arrows because all the land will be covered with thistles and thorns.
7.25: As for all the hills which used to be cared for as a garden, you will not go there for fear of thistles and thorns. They will become a place where cattle feed and where sheep will run.

8.1: Then the Lord said to me, “Take a large piece of stone and write on it in easy-to-read letters: ‘They hurry to get what they can. They run to pick up what is left.’”
8.2: And I took men who could be trusted to watch the writing, Uriah the religious leader and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah.
8.3: Then I went to the woman who spoke for God, and she was able to have a child, and gave birth to a son. Then the Lord said to me, “Name him Maher-shalal-hashbaz.
8.4: For before the boy knows how to cry out ‘My father’ or ‘My mother,’ the riches of Damascus and everything of any worth in Samaria will be carried away by the king of Assyria.”
8.5: The Lord spoke to me again, saying,
8.6: “These people have turned away from the gentle, flowing waters of Shiloah, and find joy in Rezin and the son of Remaliah.
8.7: So now, see, the Lord is ready to bring on them the strong and powerful waters of the Euphrates, the king of Assyria and all his greatness. It will rise up high and cause a flood.
8.8: Then it will flow into Judah. It will flood and pass through, and come up even to the neck. And the spread of its wings will cover the width of your land, O Immanuel.
8.9: “Be broken, O people, and be afraid. Listen, all you far places of the earth. Get ready, yet be afraid. Get ready, yet be afraid.
8.10: Make a plan, but it will come to nothing. Give your plan, but it will not be done. For God is with us.”
8.11: For the Lord said this to me with great power, and told me not to walk in the way of these people. He said,
8.12: “Do not call holy all that these people call holy. Do not fear what they fear, or be afraid of it.
8.13: It is the Lord of All Whom you should think of as holy. Let Him be the One you fear. He is the One to be afraid of.
8.14: Then He will become a holy place. But He will be a stone of trouble and a rock to fall over for both houses of Israel. He will be a net and a trap for the people of Jerusalem.
8.15: Many will fall over them. They will fall and be broken. They will be trapped and caught.”
8.16: Put together what I have said. Hold to my teachings among my followers.
8.17: I will wait for the Lord Who is hiding His face from the family of Jacob. I trust Him and hope in Him.
8.18: See, I and the children the Lord has given me are something special to see and a wonder in Israel from the Lord of All, Who lives on Mount Zion.
8.19: When they say to you, “Ask those who speak in secret with the spirits of the dead and who use their secret ways,” should not a people ask their God? Should they speak to the dead for the living?
8.20: Tell them to put their faith in the teaching and the Law. If they do not speak what this word says, it is because they have no light in them.
8.21: They will pass through the land troubled and hungry. And when they are hungry, they will be angry and curse their king and their God as they look up.
8.22: Then they will look to the earth and see trouble and darkness and suffering and will be driven out into darkness.

9.1: But there will be no more heavy hearts for those who were suffering. In the past God allowed the lands of Zebulun and Naphtali to be put to shame. In the future He will honor Galilee where those who are not Jews live and where the road to the sea is. It is on the other side of the Jordan.
9.2: The people who walk in darkness will see a great light. The light will shine on those living in the land of dark shadows.
9.3: You will make the nation great. You will give them great joy. They will be glad before You, as with the joy of gathering time, and as men have joy when they divide the riches taken after a battle.
9.4: For You will break the heavy load from their neck and shoulders. You will break the power of those who made it hard for them, as at the battle of Midian.
9.5: For every shoe of the soldiers in the battle, and every coat rolled in blood, will be burned in the fire.
9.6: For to us a Child will be born. To us a Son will be given. And the rule of the nations will be on His shoulders. His name will be called Wonderful, Teacher, Powerful God, Father Who Lives Forever, Prince of Peace.
9.7: There will be no end to His rule and His peace, upon the throne of David and over his nation. He will build it to last and keep it strong with what is right and fair and good from that time and forever. The work of the Lord of All will do this.
9.8: The Lord sends word against Jacob, and it falls on Israel.
9.9: And all the people will know it, that is, Ephraim and the people of Samaria. They say with a proud spirit in their hearts,
9.10: “The clay blocks have fallen down, but we will build again with smooth stones. The sycamore trees have been cut down, but we will put cedar trees in their place.”
9.11: So the Lord brings men from Rezin to fight against them. He makes those who hate them move to action.
9.12: The Syrians on the east and the Philistines on the west swallow Israel with an open mouth. Even with this, the Lord’s anger does not turn away. His hand is still held out.
9.13: Yet the people do not return to Him Who punished them. They do not look to the Lord of All.
9.14: So the Lord will cut off the head and tail from Israel, both palm branch and river-grass in one day.
9.15: The leaders and men of honor are the head, and the tail is the false preachers who teach lies.
9.16: For those who lead these people are leading them from the right way, and those who are led by them are going the wrong way.
9.17: So the Lord is not pleased with their young men. He does not have pity on their children who have no parents or on their women whose husbands have died. Every one of them is without God and does sinful things. Every mouth speaks foolish words. Even with all this, His anger does not turn away. His hand is still held out.
9.18: For sin burns like a fire. It burns thistles and thorns. It sets the woods on fire, and they go up in smoke.
9.19: The land is burned up by the anger of the Lord, and the people are like wood for the fire. No man shows pity on his brother.
9.20: They take what is on the right hand but still are hungry. They eat what is in the left hand but are not filled. Each of them eats the flesh of his own children.
9.21: Manasseh goes against Ephraim, and Ephraim goes against Manasseh. And together they are against Judah. Even with all this, the Lord’s anger does not turn away. His hand is still held out.

10.1: It is bad for those who make laws that are not fair. It is bad for those who make it hard for people.
10.2: They keep what is right and fair from those in need. They take away the rights of the poor of My people. They take from wives after their husbands die, and take what belongs to those who have no parents.
10.3: Now what will you do in the day of punishment, when the destroying power comes from far away? To whom will you run for help? Where will you leave your riches?
10.4: Nothing will be left to do but to bow down among those who are being taken to prison, or fall among those who are killed. Even with all this, His anger does not turn away. His hand is still held out.
10.5: It is bad for Assyria. I use Assyria like a stick to punish Israel.
10.6: I sent it against a nation without God, against the people of My anger. I sent it to take away the riches of battle, and to step hard on the people like dirt in the streets.
10.7: But this is not what is in Assyria’s mind. It does not plan this in its heart. It plans to destroy and to cut off many nations.
10.8: For it says, “Are not my princes all kings?
10.9: Is not Calno like Carchemish, or Hamath like Arpad, or Samaria like Damascus?
10.10: My hand took the nations of the false gods, whose false gods were greater than those of Jerusalem and Samaria.
10.11: Should I not do to Jerusalem and her gods just as I have done to Samaria and her gods?”
10.12: So when the Lord has completed all His work on Mount Zion and on Jerusalem, He will punish the proud heart of the king of Assyria and his proud spirit.
10.13: For the king has said, “I did this by the power of my hand and by my wisdom, for I have understanding. I moved the land-marks of the people and took their riches. Like a strong man I have brought down those who sat on thrones.
10.14: My hand has taken the riches of the people like one taken from a nest. I gathered all the earth as one gathers eggs that have been left. And there was not one that moved its wing or opened its mouth or made a sound.”
10.15: Can an ax say it is more important than the one who uses it? Is the saw more important than the one who saws with it? A stick of wood does not lift up a man. A man lifts up a stick.
10.16: So the Lord, the Lord of All, will send a wasting disease among the strong Assyrian soldiers. Under the king’s greatness a fire will be started that will burn and burn.
10.17: The light of Israel and his Holy One will become a fire. And it will burn and destroy his thorns and thistles in one day.
10.18: The Lord will destroy the greatness of the trees and the fields that give much fruit, both soul and body. It will be as when a sick man wastes away.
10.19: And the rest of his trees will be so few that a child could write them down.
10.20: In that day those of Israel and of the family of Jacob who are still alive will never again trust in the one who destroyed them. But they will trust in the Lord, the Holy One of Israel.
10.21: Some people, those who are left of Jacob, will return to the powerful God.
10.22: Even if there are as many Jews as the sand by the sea, only a few of them will return. The plan is to destroy them and it will be right and complete.
10.23: For the Lord of All will destroy everything in the whole land and do what He planned.
10.24: So the Lord, the Lord of All, says, “O My people who live in Zion, do not be afraid of the Assyrians when they come to fight against you as the Egyptians did.
10.25: For in a very little while My anger against you will come to an end and it will be turned to destroy them.”
10.26: The Lord of All will punish them like He punished Midian at the rock of Oreb. His special stick will be over the sea and He will lift it up the way He did in Egypt.
10.27: In that day the Assyrian’s load will be taken from your shoulders and neck, and it will be broken because you are so fat.
10.28: He has come against Aiath. He has passed through Migron. At Michmash he left his bags.
10.29: They have gone through a narrow path. They stayed in Geba during the night. Ramah is afraid, and Gibeah of Saul has run away.
10.30: Cry out with your voice, O people of Gallim! See, Laishah! Answer her, O Anathoth!
10.31: Madmenah has run away. The people of Gebim have looked for a safe place.
10.32: Yet today he will stop at Nob. He shakes his hand at the mountain of the people of Zion, the hill of Jerusalem.
10.33: See, the Lord, the Lord of All, will cut off the branches with a great noise. Those who stand tall will be cut down. And those who are high will be brought low.
10.34: He will cut down the many trees with an iron ax. And Lebanon will fall by the Powerful One.

11.1: Then One will come from the family of Jesse. A branch will grow out of his roots.
11.2: And the Spirit of the Lord will rest on Him, the spirit of wisdom and understanding, the spirit of wise words and strength, the spirit of much learning and the fear of the Lord.
11.3: He will be glad in the fear of the Lord. He will not judge by what His eyes see, or decide by what His ears hear.
11.4: But He will judge the poor in a right and good way. He will be fair in what He decides for the people of the earth who have much trouble. He will punish the earth with His powerful mouth, and kill the sinful with the breath of His lips.
11.5: He will wear a belt of what is right and good and faithful around His body.
11.6: The wolf will live with the lamb. The leopard will lie down with the baby goat. The calf and the young lion and the young fat animal will lie down together. And a little boy will lead them.
11.7: The cow and the bear will eat side by side. And their young will lie down together. The lion will eat straw like the ox.
11.8: The nursing child will play by the hole of the cobra. And another child will put his hand in the hole of a snake whose bite is poison.
11.9: They will not hurt or destroy in all My holy mountain. For the earth will be as full of much learning from the Lord as the seas are full of water.
11.10: In that day the nations will turn to the One from the family of Jesse. He will be honored by the people as someone special to see. And His place of rest will be full of His shining-greatness.
11.11: In that day the Lord will put out His hand a second time to bring back His people who are left. He will bring them back from Assyria, Egypt, Pathros, Cush, Elam, Shinar, Hamath, and from the islands of the sea.
11.12: He will lift up flags for the nations, and will gather together the people of Israel and of Judah who had been sent away. He will bring them back from the four corners of the earth.
11.13: Ephraim will not be jealous. Those who made it hard for Judah will be cut off. Ephraim will not be jealous of Judah, and Judah will not make it hard for Ephraim.
11.14: But they will go down against the Philistines in the west. Together they will take what belongs to the sons of the east. They will go against Edom and Moab. And they will rule the sons of Ammon.
11.15: The Lord will dry up all the tongue of the Sea of Egypt. He will wave His hand over the Euphrates River with His burning wind, and will break it into seven rivers. Men will be able to walk over it with dry feet.
11.16: And there will be a road from Assyria for those of His people who will be left just as it was for Israel when they came up from the land of Egypt.

12.1: You will say on that day, “I will give thanks to You, O Lord. Even though You were angry with me, Your anger is turned away and You comfort me.
12.2: See, God saves me. I will trust and not be afraid. For the Lord God is my strength and song. And He has become the One Who saves me.”
12.3: As water from a well brings joy to the thirsty, so people have joy when He saves them.
12.4: In that day you will say, “Give thanks to the Lord. Call on His name. Make known His works among the people. Help them remember that His name is honored.”
12.5: Sing praises to the Lord, for He has done great things. Let this be known in all the earth.
12.6: Call out and sing for joy, O people of Zion. For the Holy One of Israel is great among you.

13.1: The special word about Babylon which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw:
13.2: Lift up a flag on the hill without trees. Call out to the people. Wave the hand for them to go into the gates of the princes.
13.3: I have told My holy ones, and My powerful soldiers who take pride in their strength, to carry out My anger.
13.4: Listen to the noise on the mountains, like that of many people! Listen to the loud sound of the many people, of nations gathered together! The Lord of All is gathering an army for battle.
13.5: They are coming from a far country, from the end of the heavens. The Lord and all He is using to show His anger are coming to destroy the whole land.
13.6: Cry out in sorrow, for the day of the Lord is near! It will come as a destroying power from the All-powerful.
13.7: So all hands will become weak, and every man’s heart will melt.
13.8: They will be filled with fear. Pain and suffering will take hold of them. They will suffer like a woman giving birth. They will look surprised at one another, their faces burning.
13.9: See, the day of the Lord is coming, without pity and with much anger. He is coming to destroy the land and its sinners from it.
13.10: The stars of heaven and every group of stars will not give out their light. The sun will be dark when it comes up, and the moon will not give its light.
13.11: This is how I will punish the world for its sin, and the sinful for their wrong-doing. I will also put an end to those who are proud. And I will put to shame those who make it hard for others and show no pity.
13.12: I will make men so few that they will be of more worth than pure gold, even the gold of Ophir.
13.13: I will make the heavens shake. And the earth will be shaken from its place with the anger of the Lord of All in the day of His burning anger.
13.14: Every man will turn to his own people and run to his own land like a hunted gazelle or like sheep with no shepherd.
13.15: Anyone who is found will have a spear put through him. And anyone who is caught will fall by the sword.
13.16: Their little ones will be broken in pieces in front of their eyes. Their things will be taken from their houses. And their wives will be carried away.
13.17: See, I am going to make the Medes go against them, who will not want silver or be happy with gold.
13.18: Their bows will cut down the young men. They will have no pity on babies. Their eyes will not pity children.
13.19: And Babylon, the beauty of nations, the shining-greatness and pride of the Babylonians, will be as when God destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah.
13.20: People will never live in it again, even all the people-to-come. No Arab will set up his tent there. No shepherds will make their flocks lie down there.
13.21: But wild animals of the desert will lie down there. Their houses will be full of owls. Ostriches will live there, and wild goats will play there.
13.22: Hyenas will make noise in their strong towers, and wild dogs in their beautiful houses. The end of her time is near. Her days will be few.

14.1: The Lord will have loving-pity on Jacob and will again choose Israel. He will have them return to live in their own land. Then people from other countries will come and be with them, and will join themselves to the family of Jacob.
14.2: Nations will take them and bring them to their place. The family of Israel will own them in the Lord’s land as men and women servants. They will take those who had taken them away and they will rule over those who had made it hard for them.
14.3: When the Lord gives you rest from your pain and trouble and the hard work which you were made to do,
14.4: you will speak against the king of Babylon, and say, “How the one who made it hard for us has been stopped! How his anger has been stopped!
14.5: The Lord has broken the walking stick of the sinful, the power of rulers,
14.6: which used to beat the people in anger without stopping. The nations were ruled in anger. It was very hard for the people and there was no pity shown to them.
14.7: “Now the whole earth is at rest and quiet. They sing out with joy.
14.8: Even the cypress trees and the cedars of Lebanon are glad over you, and say, ‘Since you were cut down no one comes to cut us down.’
14.9: The world of the dead below wants to meet you when you come. It wakes up the spirits of the dead for you, all the leaders of the earth. It raises all the kings of the nations from their thrones.
14.10: All of them will speak and say to you, ‘Even you have become as weak as we. You have become like us.
14.11: Your honor and power along with the music of your harps have been brought down to the place of the dead. Worms are spread out as your bed under you and worms cover you.’
14.12: “How you have fallen from heaven, O shining one, son of the morning! You have been cut down to the earth, you who have made the nations weak!
14.13: You said in your heart, ‘I will go up to heaven. I will raise my throne above the stars of God. And I will sit on the mount of meeting in the far north.
14.14: I will go much higher than the clouds. I will make myself like the Most High.’
14.15: But you will be brought down to the place of the dead, to the bottom of the grave.
14.16: Those who see you will look hard at you and think about you, and say, ‘Is this the man who made the earth shake with fear, who shook nations?
14.17: Is this the man who made the world like a desert and destroyed its cities, who did not let those whom he had put in prison go home?’
14.18: “All the kings of the nations lie in greatness, each in his own grave.
14.19: But you have been thrown out of your grave like a hated part of the family. You are clothed with the dead who were killed with a sword, who go down to the stones of the grave, like a dead body crushed under foot.
14.20: You will not be joined with them when you are buried, because you have destroyed your country. You have killed your people. May the children of sinners never be spoken about again!
14.21: Make a place ready for his sons to be killed because of the sin of their fathers. They must not come into power and take the earth, and fill the world with cities.”
14.22: “I will come against them,” says the Lord of All. “And I will cut off from Babylon its name and people, its children and their children,” says the Lord.
14.23: “I will turn it into a place for hedgehogs, full of pools of water. And I will go over it and destroy it,” says the Lord of All.
14.24: The Lord of All has promised, “It will happen just as I have planned it. As I have planned, so will it be.
14.25: I will break Assyria in My land. I will crush him under foot on My mountains. Then his load will be taken from My people. His load will be taken from their shoulder.”
14.26: This is the plan made against the whole earth and this is the hand that is put out against all the nations.
14.27: For the Lord of All has planned, and who can keep it from happening? Who can turn His hand back?
14.28: In the year that King Ahaz died this special word came:
14.29: “Do not be glad, O Philistia, all of you, because the special stick that made it hard for you is broken. One snake dies and a worse one comes, a snake that can fly.
14.30: The poor will eat. Those in need will lie down and be safe. I will destroy all of you with hunger and it will kill those who are left.
14.31: Cry out, O gate. Cry, O city. All you Philistines are weak in heart. For smoke comes from the north, and everyone keeps his place in his army.
14.32: What answer will be given to the men sent by the nation? That the Lord is the builder of Zion, and it will be a safe place for His people who are poor and troubled.”

15.1: The special word against Moab: Ar of Moab is destroyed and laid waste in a night. And in a night Kir of Moab is destroyed and laid waste.
15.2: They have gone up to the house of worship and to Dibon. They have gone to the high places to cry. Moab cries over Nebo and Medeba. The hair has been cut from everyone’s head and face.
15.3: In their streets they have dressed themselves with cloth made from hair. On the tops of their houses and in their open spaces everyone is crying with many tears.
15.4: Heshbon and Elealeh cry out also. Their voice is heard as far as Jahaz. So the soldiers of Moab cry out. Moab’s soul shakes within him.
15.5: My heart cries out for Moab. His men have run away as far as Zoar and Eglath-shelishiyah. For they go up the hill of Luhith crying. On the road to Horonaim they cry in sorrow over their being destroyed.
15.6: For the waters of Nimrim have been laid waste. The grass is dried up. The new grass died out. There is no green thing.
15.7: So the many things they have gathered and stored up they carry away over the river of Arabim.
15.8: The cry of sorrow has gone around the land of Moab. Its noise is heard as far as Eglaim and Beer-elim.
15.9: The waters of Dimon are full of blood. Yet I will bring more troubles to Dimon. I will bring a lion upon those of Moab who have run away, and upon the people of the land who are still alive.

16.1: Send lambs as taxes to the ruler of the land, from Sela by the way of the desert to the mountain of the people of Zion.
16.2: Then, like birds driven from their nest, the people of Moab will be where the Arnon River can be crossed.
16.3: “Give us words of wisdom. Do what is right for us. Make your shadow like night at noonday. Hide those who have been sent away. Do not go against those who are running for their lives.
16.4: Let those of Moab who have been sent away stay with you. Hide them from the one who destroys.” For the one who uses sinful power has come to an end, and trouble has stopped. Those who make it hard for the people have gone from the land.
16.5: A throne will be set up in loving-kindness. A faithful judge will sit on it from the family of David. He will be fair as he judges, and will be quick to do what is right and good.
16.6: We have heard of the pride of Moab, how very proud he is. We have heard of how proud he is of himself and of his anger. His proud words are false.
16.7: So Moab will cry out. Everyone of Moab will cry out. You will cry for the dried-grape cakes of Kir-hareseth, as if you were in the worst trouble.
16.8: The fields of Heshbon and the vines of Sibmah have dried up. The lords of the nations have crushed under foot its best vines, which went as far as Jazer and the desert. They spread themselves out and passed over the sea.
16.9: So I will cry with much sorrow for Jazer and for the vines of Sibmah. I will make you wet with my tears, O Heshbon and Elealeh, because there is nothing to gather from your summer fruits.
16.10: Happiness and joy are taken away from the field that gives much fruit. No songs are sung in the grape-fields. No one crushes grapes to make wine, for I have stopped the cry of joy.
16.11: So my heart cries with sorrow for Moab like a harp. Inside myself I cry for Kir-hareseth.
16.12: When Moab goes to his high place, he will only become tired. When he goes to his holy place to pray, it will do him no good.
16.13: This is the word which the Lord spoke before about Moab.
16.14: But now the Lord says, “In three years, as a servant would count them, the shining-greatness of Moab and all his many people will be hated. And those left alive will be very few and weak.”

17.1: The special word about Damascus: “See, Damascus will no longer be a city. It will be destroyed and laid waste.
17.2: The cities of Aroer are left empty. They will be for the flocks to lie down in, and no one will make them afraid.
17.3: The strong city will be gone from Ephraim. Damascus will no longer rule. And those of Syria who are left alive will be like the shining-greatness of the sons of Israel,” says the Lord of All.
17.4: In that day Jacob will lose his shining-greatness. And he will lose the fat of his flesh.
17.5: It will be like one who gathers the standing grain, taking the ears of grain with his arm or like one who gathers the ears of grain in the valley of Rephaim.
17.6: Yet some good will be left in it, as when an olive tree is shaken. There will still be two or three olives on the highest branch, and four or five on the branches of a tree that gives much fruit, says the Lord God of Israel.
17.7: In that day man will turn to his Maker. His eyes will look to the Holy One of Israel.
17.8: He will not look to the altars, the work of his hands. He will not look to what his fingers have made, or to the false goddess Asherah and the altars of special perfume.
17.9: In that day their strong cities will be like places left empty among the trees, or like high branches which they left behind because of the sons of Israel. The land will be laid waste.
17.10: For you have forgotten the God Who saves you. You have not remembered the rock where you are safe. So you plant beautiful plants, and put them with the vine-cuttings of a strange god.
17.11: In the day that you plant it you fence it in, and in the morning your seed is growing. But its fruit will waste away in a day of sickness and pain which cannot be healed.
17.12: Listen to the cry of sorrow of many people. They sound like the noise of the seas and the noise of nations! They sound like the rushing of powerful waters.
17.13: The nations move on like the noise of many waters. But God will speak sharp words to them and they will run far away. They will be blown away like the part of grain that is of no worth by the wind in the mountains. They will be like dust blown around in a storm.
17.14: At evening time there is much fear! Before morning, they are gone. This will be what will come to those who take what belongs to us. It will be what happens to those who rob us.

18.1: Trouble will come to the land on the other side of the rivers of Cush where the sound of wings is heard.
18.2: From that land men are sent by the sea in boats made from tall river-grass. Go, you fast men, to a nation tall and smooth, to a people who fill others with fear both near and far. Go to the powerful nation that rules over those who hate it, whose land is divided by rivers.
18.3: All you people of the world, you who live on the earth, as soon as a flag is raised on the mountain, you will see it. As soon as the horn is sounded, you will hear it.
18.4: For the Lord has said to me, “I will be quiet and watch from the place where I live, like shining heat in the sunshine, like a cloud of fog in the heat of gathering time.”
18.5: For before the gathering time, as soon as the bud blossoms and the grape is ready to eat, He will cut off the new branches with knives and will cut away the spreading branches.
18.6: They will be left for the birds of the mountains and for the wild animals of the earth. The birds will spend the summer eating them. And all the wild animals of the earth will eat them during the winter.
18.7: At that time tall people with smooth skin will bring gifts to the Lord of All. These people make others afraid both near and far. They are a strong and powerful nation who rule over others, whose land is divided by rivers. And they will go to Mount Zion, the place of the Name of the Lord of All.

19.1: The special word about Egypt: See, the Lord is traveling on a fast cloud and is coming to Egypt. The false gods of Egypt shake in fear before Him. The hearts of the Egyptians become weak.
19.2: “I will make Egyptians go against Egyptians. Each of them will fight against his brother, and each against his neighbor. City will fight against city, and nation against nation.
19.3: Then the spirit of the Egyptians will become weak within them. And I will bring their plans to nothing. They will go to false gods and spirits of the dead for help, and to those who speak with spirits of the dead and use their secret ways.
19.4: Then I will give the Egyptians into the hand of a bad ruler. An angry king will rule over them,” says the Lord God of All.
19.5: The waters of the sea will dry up. The river will become dry.
19.6: Manmade rivers will smell bad. The small rivers of Egypt will dry up. And the plants by the rivers will waste away.
19.7: The grass by the side of the Nile and all that is planted by the Nile will become dry, will be driven away, and be no more.
19.8: The fishermen will cry in sorrow. All those who fish for a living in the Nile River will be filled with sorrow. And those who put out nets on its waters will become weak.
19.9: Those who make linen and white cloth will be very troubled.
19.10: The pillars of Egypt will be crushed. All the able workmen will be filled with sorrow.
19.11: The king’s sons of Zoan are very foolish. The words of Pharaoh’s wisest men are foolish words. How can you men say to Pharaoh, “I am a son of the wise, a son of early kings”?
19.12: Where then are your wise men? Let them tell you. And let them understand what the Lord of All has planned against Egypt.
19.13: The king’s sons of Zoan have become fools. The king’s sons of Memphis have been fooled. The heads of her family groups have led Egypt from the right way.
19.14: The Lord has mixed a troubled spirit within her. They have led Egypt the wrong way in all that it does, as a drunk man walks from side to side in what he has spit up.
19.15: And there will be no work in Egypt and nothing can be done by anyone, its head or tail, its palm branch or river-grass.
19.16: In that day the Egyptians will be like women. They will shake with fear because of the hand which the Lord of All is going to wave over them.
19.17: The land of Judah will fill Egypt with fear. Whoever hears its name will be afraid of it, because of the plan which the Lord of All is making against them.
19.18: In that day five cities in the land of Egypt will be speaking the language of Canaan and promising to follow the Lord of All. One will be called the City of Destruction.
19.19: In that day there will be an altar to the Lord in the center of the land of Egypt, and an altar to the Lord by the side of its land.
19.20: It will be something special to see, to make the Lord of All known in the land of Egypt. For they will cry to the Lord because of those who make it hard for them. And He will send a Powerful One to save them, and He will take them out of trouble.
19.21: The Lord will make Himself known to Egypt, and in that day the Egyptians will know the Lord. They will even worship with gifts on the altar. They will make promises to the Lord and keep them.
19.22: And the Lord will punish Egypt, but then He will heal them. So they will return to the Lord, and He will answer their prayers and heal them.
19.23: In that day there will be a road from Egypt to Assyria. The Assyrians will go to Egypt, and the Egyptians will go to Assyria. The Egyptians will worship with the Assyrians.
19.24: In that day Israel will be the third country with Egypt and Assyria, a good and respected nation on the earth,
19.25: to whom the Lord of All has brought good, saying, “Good will come to Egypt My people, and Assyria the work of My hands, and Israel My chosen people.”

20.1: In the year that Sargon the king of Assyria sent his head captain to fight against Ashdod, he took it in battle.
20.2: At that time the Lord spoke through Isaiah the son of Amoz, saying, “Go and take off the clothes made from hair, and take your shoes off your feet.” And he did so, going without clothes and shoes.
20.3: The Lord said, “My servant Isaiah has gone without clothing and shoes for three years as something special to be seen against Egypt and Cush.
20.4: So the king of Assyria will take away the people of Egypt and Cush, young and old, without clothes or shoes. Their bodies will not be covered, to the shame of Egypt.
20.5: Then they will be ashamed and troubled because of Cush their hope and Egypt their pride.
20.6: The people living on this island will say in that day, ‘See, this is what has happened to those in whom we hoped, and to whom we ran for help to be saved from the king of Assyria. Now how can we get away?’”

21.1: The special word about the place by the sea where no people live: As wind-storms in the Negev go rushing through, it comes from the desert, from a bad land.
21.2: A hard special dream has been shown to me. The one who hurts still goes on hurting others, and the destroyer still destroys. Go up, Elam. Gather your armies around, Media. I will bring an end to all the crying she has caused.
21.3: For this reason my body is full of suffering. Pains have taken hold of me like the pains of a woman giving birth. I am so troubled that I cannot hear. I am so afraid that I cannot see.
21.4: My mind turns. Fear has come over me. The evening I have waited so long for has been turned into a time of shaking with fear.
21.5: They set the tables. They spread out the cloth. They eat and drink. Rise up, captains, oil the battle-coverings!
21.6: For the Lord says to me, “Go, set a man to keep watch. Let him tell what he sees.
21.7: When he sees men riding on horses, two by two, and men on donkeys, and men on camels, let him be very careful to watch.”
21.8: Then the watchman called out like a lion, “O Lord, I stand watching from the watch-tower at all times during the day. And I stand there every night.
21.9: Now see, here comes an army of men riding on horses, two by two.” One answered and said, “Fallen, fallen is Babylon. All the objects of her gods are broken to pieces on the ground.”
21.10: O my people of Israel, you were beaten and crushed like grain! What I have heard from the Lord of All, the God of Israel, I make known to you.
21.11: The special word about Edom: One is calling to me from Seir, “Watchman, what is the time of night? Watchman, what is the time of night?”
21.12: The watchman says, “The morning comes, but also the night. If you have questions to ask, ask them, and come back again.”
21.13: The special word about Arabia: You must stay the night among the trees of Arabia, O traveling people of Dedanim.
21.14: Bring water for the thirsty. O people of the land of Tema, give bread to the one who is running from trouble.
21.15: They are running from swords, from lifted swords, from bows that are ready to shoot, and from the trouble of battle.
21.16: For the Lord said to me, “In a year, as the servant would count it, all the greatness of Kedar will come to an end.
21.17: And the rest of the men who use the bow, the strong men of the sons of Kedar, will be few. For the Lord God of Israel has spoken.”

22.1: The special word about the Valley of Visions: What is wrong, that you have all gone up to the house tops,
22.2: you who were full of noise, you loud town, you joy-filled city? Your dead were not killed with the sword. They did not die in battle.
22.3: All your rulers have run away together, and were taken without using the bow. All of you who were found were taken away together, even though you had run far away.
22.4: So I said, “Turn your eyes away from me. Let me cry with much sorrow. Do not try to comfort me about my people being destroyed.”
22.5: For the Lord God of All has a day of fear, crushing down, and trouble in the Valley of Vision. There is a breaking down of walls and a crying out to the mountain.
22.6: Elam took up the arrows with the war-wagons, soldiers and horsemen. And Kir let the battle-covering be seen.
22.7: Your best valleys were full of war-wagons, and the horsemen took their places at the gate.
22.8: Then God took away the safe-covering of Judah. In that day you trusted in the objects you had to fight with that were stored in the house among the trees.
22.9: You saw that there were many broken places in the wall of the city of David. You stored water in the lower pool.
22.10: Then you numbered the houses of Jerusalem, and tore down houses to make the wall stronger.
22.11: You made a place to store water between the two walls for the waters of the old pool. But you did not trust in God Who made it. You did not think about Him Who planned it long ago.
22.12: So in that day the Lord God of All called you to cry in sorrow, to cut off the hair from your head, and to wear cloth made from hair.
22.13: But instead, there is joy and happiness, killing of cattle and sheep, eating of meat, and drinking of wine. You say, “Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we die.”
22.14: But the Lord of All has made Himself known to me. The Lord God of All says, “For sure you will not be forgiven for this sin until you die.”
22.15: The Lord God of All says, “Come, go to this person in Shebna who is taking care of the king’s house. Say to him,
22.16: ‘What right do you have here? Who told you that you could cut out a grave for yourself here? You cut out a grave on a high place! You cut a resting place for yourself in the rock!
22.17: See, the Lord will throw you away without pity, O you strong man. He will take a strong hold of you
22.18: and roll you up like a ball to be thrown into a wide land. There you will die, and there your great war-wagons will be. You are a shame to your king’s house.’
22.19: I will throw you out of your place of power. I will take you down from your place.
22.20: In that day I will call My servant Eliakim, the son of Hilkiah.
22.21: I will clothe him with your coat, and tie your belt around him. I will give him the power you had. He will become a father to the people of Jerusalem and to the family of Judah.
22.22: Then I will put on his shoulder the rule of the family of David. What he opens, no one will shut. What he shuts, no one will open.
22.23: I will drive him like a nail in a hard place. He will become a throne of honor to his father’s house.
22.24: So they will put on him all the honor of his father’s house, and of his children, and every little dish, from the cups to all the jars.
22.25: “In that day,” says the Lord of All, “the nail driven in a hard place will give way. It will break off and fall, and the load hanging on it will be cut off. For the Lord has spoken.”

23.1: The special word about Tyre: Cry out in sorrow, O ships of Tarshish. For Tyre is destroyed, so that there is no house or safe place for ships. It is made known to them from the land of Cyprus.
23.2: Be quiet, you people who live on the islands, you traders of Sidon. You sent men to cross the sea
23.3: and go on many waters. The grain of the Nile, that was gathered beside that River, made money for Tyre who was the trader of the nations.
23.4: Be ashamed, O Sidon, the strong-place of the sea. The sea speaks and says, “I have not suffered or given birth. I have not brought up young men or young women.”
23.5: When the news comes to Egypt, they will be in pain when they hear about Tyre.
23.6: Pass over to Tarshish. Cry out in sorrow, O people of the islands.
23.7: Is this your joy-filled city, whose beginning was long ago, whose feet have taken her to live in places far away?
23.8: Who has planned this against Tyre, the giver of crowns, whose traders were princes and the honored of the earth?
23.9: The Lord of All has planned it, to put to shame the pride of all beauty, and to take honor away from all the honored of the earth.
23.10: Flow over your land like the Nile, O people of Tarshish. There is nothing holding you back any more.
23.11: He has put out His hand over the sea. He has made the nations shake with fear. The Lord has said that the strong-places of Canaan must be destroyed.
23.12: He has said, “You will not be filled with joy anymore, O pure crushed daughters of Sidon. Get up and go over to Cyprus. Even there you will not find any rest.”
23.13: It was the Babylonians, not the Assyrians, who let the wild animals come upon Tyre. They built towers for their armies. They tore down her beautiful houses. They destroyed her.
23.14: Cry out in sorrow, O ships of Tarshish, for your strong-place is destroyed.
23.15: In that day Tyre will be forgotten for seventy years like the days of one king. At the end of seventy years it will happen to Tyre as in the song of the woman who sells the use of her body:
23.16: “Take your harp and walk through the city, O forgotten woman who sells the use of her body. Play the strings well. Sing many songs, that you may be remembered.”
23.17: At the end of seventy years, the Lord will visit Tyre. Then she will return to her sinful woman’s pay. She will be as a woman who sells the use of her body to all the nations on the earth.
23.18: Her riches and her pay for selling the use of her body will be set apart to the Lord. It will not be stored up or saved. But what she receives will give much food and good clothes to those who live for the Lord.

24.1: See, the Lord will lay the earth waste. He will destroy it, turn its ground up-side-down, and send its people everywhere.
24.2: What happens to the people will happen to the religious leader. What happens to the man servant will happen to his owner. The woman servant will be like her owner. The buyer will be like the seller. The giver will be like the receiver. The one who lets another use his money will be like the one who uses it.
24.3: All the earth will be laid waste and destroyed, for the Lord has said this.
24.4: The earth cries in sorrow and wastes away. The world becomes weak with sorrow and wastes away, together with the honored people of the earth.
24.5: The earth has been made unclean by its people. They have sinned and not obeyed the laws, and have broken the agreement that was to be forever.
24.6: So the earth is cursed and those who live in it suffer for their guilt. So the people of the earth are burned, and few men are left.
24.7: The new wine dries up and the vine wastes away. All the glad in heart are in sorrow.
24.8: The happiness of the music-makers stops. The noise of those filled with joy stops. The happiness of the harp stops.
24.9: They do not drink wine with singing. Strong drink tastes bad to those who drink it.
24.10: The city of trouble is broken down. Every house is shut up so no one may go in.
24.11: There is a crying out in the streets about the wine. All joy turns to darkness. The happiness of the earth is gone.
24.12: The city is laid waste. The gate is broken to pieces.
24.13: For this is how it will be on the earth among the nations. It will be like the shaking of an olive tree, and like what is left after the grapes have been gathered.
24.14: They raise their voices. They call out for joy. They cry out from the west about the wonderful power of the Lord.
24.15: So honor the Lord in the east. Honor the name of the Lord God of Israel in the islands of the sea.
24.16: From the ends of the earth we hear songs: “Praise the One Who is right and good.” But I say, “I waste away! I waste away! It is bad for me! The false ones are not faithful. Yes, their way is very false.”
24.17: Fear and the deep hole and the trap are before you, O people of the earth.
24.18: He who runs from the news of trouble will fall into a deep hole. And he who comes out of the hole will be caught in a trap. For the windows of heaven are opened, and the earth shakes.
24.19: The earth is broken in pieces. The earth is torn apart. The earth is very shaken.
24.20: The earth turns from one side to the other side like a drunk man. It shakes like a tent because its sin is heavy upon it. It will fall, never to rise again.
24.21: In that day the Lord will punish the powers of heaven above, and the kings of the earth below.
24.22: They will be gathered together like those in a prison. They will be kept in a deep, dark prison, and after many days they will be punished.
24.23: Then the moon will be dark and the sun will not shine, for the Lord of All will rule on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem. And in front of His leaders, He will let His shining-greatness be seen.

25.1: O Lord, You are my God. I will praise You. I will give thanks to Your name. For You have been faithful to do great things, plans that You made long ago.
25.2: For You have laid waste a city. You have destroyed a strong city. The beautiful house of strangers is a city no more. And it will never be built again.
25.3: So strong people will honor You. Cities of nations that show no pity will fear You.
25.4: For You have been a strong-place for those who could not help themselves and for those in need because of much trouble. You have been a safe place from the storm and a shadow from the heat. For the breath of the one who shows no pity is like a storm against a wall.
25.5: Like heat in a dry place, You quiet the noise of the strangers. Like heat by the shadow of a cloud, the song of the one who shows no pity is made quiet.
25.6: On this mountain the Lord of All will make a supper of good things ready for all people. It will be a supper of good wine, of the best foods, and of fine wine.
25.7: And on this mountain He will destroy the covering which is over all people, the covering which is spread over all nations.
25.8: He will take away death for all time. The Lord God will dry tears from all faces. He will take away the shame of His people from all the earth. For the Lord has spoken.
25.9: It will be said in that day, “See, this is our God. We have waited for Him, that He might save us. This is the Lord for Whom we have waited. Let us be glad and full of joy because He saves us.”
25.10: For the hand of the Lord will rest on this mountain. And Moab will be crushed in his place, as straw is crushed down in animal waste.
25.11: Moab will spread out his hands in it, as a man spreads out his hands to swim. But the Lord will put his pride to shame, together with the sinful work of his hands.
25.12: And the Lord will bring down your high walls built for war and lay them low. He will throw them to the ground, even to the dust.

26.1: In that day this song will be sung in the land of Judah: “We have a strong city. The Lord saves us and puts up walls to keep us safe.
26.2: Open the gates, that the nation that is right with God may come in, the one that keeps faithful.
26.3: You will keep the man in perfect peace whose mind is kept on You, because he trusts in You.
26.4: Trust in the Lord forever. For the Lord God is a Rock that lasts forever.
26.5: For He has brought down low those who live on a high place, the high city. He lays it low. He lays it low to the ground. He throws it to the dust.
26.6: It will be crushed under foot, under the feet of those who have suffered and the steps of those who cannot help themselves.”
26.7: The way of the man who is right with God is smooth. O Upright One, make the path straight of those who are right with You.
26.8: While following in Your ways, O Lord, we have waited for You. To remember You and Your name is the desire of our souls.
26.9: My soul has a desire for You in the night. Yes, my spirit within me looks for You in the morning. For when you punish the earth, the people of the world learn what is right and good.
26.10: When favor is shown to the sinful, he does not learn what is right and good. He goes on doing what is wrong in the land of those who are right. He does not see the wonderful power of the Lord.
26.11: O Lord, Your hand is lifted up but they do not see it. Let them see Your care for Your people and be ashamed. Let fire destroy those who hate You.
26.12: O Lord, You will give us peace, for You have done all our works for us.
26.13: O Lord our God, other lords than You have ruled us, but Your name alone is the One we honor.
26.14: They are dead, and will not live. Their spirits will not return. So You have punished and destroyed them. You have caused them all to be forgotten.
26.15: You have made the nation great, O Lord. You have made the nation great. You have received much praise. You have made the land larger.
26.16: O Lord, they looked for You in their trouble. They could only say a quiet prayer while You were punishing them.
26.17: As the woman who is going to have a baby comes close to the time to give birth, she suffers and cries out in her pains. This is how we were before You, O Lord.
26.18: We suffered in pain. We gave birth, as it were, only to wind. We could not bring the world out of its trouble. And no people of the earth were born.
26.19: Your dead will live. Their dead bodies will rise. You who lie in the dust, wake up and call out for joy. For as the water on the grass in the morning brings new life, the earth will bring back to life those who have been dead.
26.20: Come, my people, go into your rooms. Close your doors behind you. Hide for a little while until God’s anger is past.
26.21: For see, the Lord is about to come out from His place to punish the people of the earth for their sin. And the earth will let the blood be seen that has poured on her. She will no longer cover her dead.

27.1: In that day the Lord will punish Leviathan, the large snake-like sea animal, with His sharp and great and powerful sword. He will punish Leviathan the turning snake, and kill the big dragon that lives in the sea.
27.2: In that day it will be said: “Sing about a grape-field of wine!
27.3: I, the Lord, am its keeper. I water it all the time. I watch over it day and night so no one will hurt it.
27.4: I am not angry. If someone were to give Me thistles and thorns in battle, I would step on them. I would burn them together.
27.5: Or let him trust in Me to keep him safe. Let him make peace with Me. Yes, let him make peace with Me.”
27.6: In the days to come Jacob will take root. Israel will flower and begin to grow, and fill the whole world with fruit.
27.7: Has the Lord punished Israel as He punished those who went against Israel? Or have as many people of Israel been killed as their killers were killed?
27.8: You showed Your anger towards them by driving them out of the land. You moved them out with Your strong wind on the day of the east wind.
27.9: So by this Jacob’s sin will be forgiven. This will be the full price of taking his sin away: When he crushes all the altar stones into fine pieces, so the wooden female goddess Asherah and the altars of special perfume will not stand.
27.10: The city made strong for battle is empty and alone, a place left alone like the desert. The calves eat there, and they lie down and eat from its branches.
27.11: When its branches are dry, they are broken off. Women come and make a fire with them. They are not a people of understanding, so their Maker will not have pity on them. The One Who made them will not show kindness to them.
27.12: In that day the Lord will beat out His grain from the flowing river of the Euphrates to the river of Egypt. And you will be gathered up one by one, O sons of Israel.
27.13: In that day a great horn will be blown. Those who were dying in the land of Assyria and those who were sent everywhere through the land of Egypt will come and worship the Lord on the holy mountain at Jerusalem.

28.1: It is a time of trouble to the crown of pride and to the drunk men of Ephraim, whose shining beauty is a dying flower. It is at the head of the rich valley of those who have taken too much wine!
28.2: See, the Lord has one who is strong and powerful, like a storm of hail, a destroying storm. As with a flood of powerful waters flowing over, He will bring them down to the earth with His hand.
28.3: The crown of pride, the drunk men of Ephraim, will be crushed under foot.
28.4: The dying flower of its shining beauty which is at the head of the rich valley will be like the first fig grown before the summer. When one sees it, he takes it in his hand and eats it.
28.5: In that day the Lord of All will be a crown of shining-greatness, a beautiful crown to those who are left of His people.
28.6: He will be a spirit of what is fair to him who judges the people. He will be a strength to those who turn back the battle at the gate.
28.7: These also walk from one side to the other side because of wine and strong drink. The religious leaders and the men who tell what will happen in the future make mistakes because of strong drink. They are troubled by wine. They walk from side to side because of strong drink. They make mistakes as they have special dreams. And they make mistakes when judging between right and wrong.
28.8: All the tables are covered with what they have spit up. There is no place that is clean.
28.9: “Who is it He is trying to teach? To whom will He tell what He has to say? Children finished with their nursing and just taken from the breast?
28.10: For He says, ‘Law on law, law on law, rule on rule, rule on rule, a little here, a little there.’”
28.11: The Lord will speak to these people through men from other lands and in strange languages.
28.12: He Who said to them, “This is rest, give rest to the tired and weak.” And, “This is the place to rest,” but they would not listen.
28.13: So the Word of the Lord to them will be, “Law on law, law on law, rule on rule, rule on rule, a little here, a little there,” that they may go and fall back, be broken, trapped, and taken away by those who hate them.
28.14: So hear the Word of the Lord, you who laugh at the truth, who rule the people in Jerusalem!
28.15: You have said, “We have made an agreement with death. With the place of the dead we have made an agreement. The destroying flood will not touch us when it passes by. We have made lies our safe place. We have hidden ourselves with what is false.”
28.16: So the Lord God says, “See, I lay in Jerusalem a Stone of great worth to build upon, a tested Stone. Anyone who puts his trust in Him will not be afraid of what will happen.
28.17: And I will use what is fair to decide about the base. And I will use what is right and good to make it straight. Then hail will take away all the lies you depend on, and the waters will flow over the place where you hide.
28.18: Your agreement with death will come to an end. Your agreement with the place of the dead will be stopped. When a flood of trouble passes through, you will be beaten down by it.
28.19: As often as it passes through, it will take you. And it will pass through morning after morning, anytime during the day or night. To understand what it means will bring much fear.”
28.20: The bed is too short to lie on in comfort. And the covering is too small to put around yourself.
28.21: For the Lord will rise up as at Mount Perazim. He will be angry as in the valley of Gibeon, to do what He needs to do, His strange act, and to do His work, His different kind of work.
28.22: So now do not laugh, or your chains will be made stronger. I have heard that the Lord God of All plans to destroy the whole earth.
28.23: Listen and hear my voice. Listen and hear my words.
28.24: Does the farmer plow all the time to plant seed? Does he keep on turning and digging up the ground?
28.25: When he gets the ground ready to plant, does he not sow dill seeds and cummin seeds and wheat in rows? Does he not put barley in its place, and rye in the right place?
28.26: For his God tells him what to do and teaches him the right way.
28.27: Dill is not crushed with a crushing object. And the wagon wheel is not rolled over cummin. But dill is beaten out with a stick, and cummin with a heavy stick.
28.28: Grain for bread is crushed. He does not keep on crushing it forever. When he drives his wagon-wheel over it with his horses, it does not crush it.
28.29: This also comes from the Lord of All, Who has given wonderful wise words and great wisdom.

29.1: It is bad for Ariel, Ariel the city where David once set up his tents! Add year to year. Keep your special suppers at the right times.
29.2: I will bring trouble to Ariel. She will be a city of sorrow and crying. She will be like an altar covered with blood to me.
